category.term: 3089~Paula Abdul~The X Factor (TV Show)~Nicole Scherzinger~Rachel Crow
category.label: InformQString

content.div:
Hollywood insiders were shocked, shocked by the news that X Factor host Steve Jones would not be returning to the sophomore TV singing competition program this fall.

Their shock was more genuine, though, when it became known that Paula Abdul and Nicole Scherzinger would not be invited back, either.

X Factor insiders may have a heads-up, though, as early as Dec. 8, following an acrimonious contestant elimination that proved to be one of the TV season's ugliest, most unpleasant onscreen moments -- and a reminder that, for all the manipulation and contrived drama, live TV is, in fact, live.

That moment -- which many X Factor fans blamed, rightly or wrongly, on Scherzinger and, to a lesser extent, Abdul -- saw 13-year-old Rachel Crow sent home in favour of Marcus Canty, an arguably less accomplished performer many X followers felt had already outstayed his welcome on a TV singing competition still struggling to find the right tone.

Scherzinger held the deciding vote that night. Instead, saying the decision was too difficult, she opted not to cast a vote at all, leaving it to a predetermined vote to decide. Many onlookers felt that, by not casting a vote, Scherzinger had abdicated her responsibility as a judge. Abdul was seen to be complicit in her decision.

When Crow, clearly unprepared for the spotlight of fame and sudden misfortune, collapsed to the stage and cried, the unexpected twist may have made for great television, but it was difficult to watch.

At the time, The X Factor was already dealing with dashed expectations as a TV spectacle. It was nowhere near the ratings grabber and pop-cultural lightning rod many predicted leading up to the show's debut in September. The X Factor is a sensation in the U.K., and many expected a similar reception in the U.S. The X Factor aired in Canada on CTV, where it was a modest but by no means chart-topping ratings hit.

The events of Dec. 8 merely crystallized in many viewers' minds the growing belief that The X Factor was long on glitz and glamour but short on heart and soul.

Simon Cowell, the program's creator, senior executive producer and the person believed most responsible for this week's lineup changes, was livid at the time.

Crow was a sentimental favourite with the audience, because of her bubbly personality, preternaturally mature voice and difficult childhood. Crow was adopted as an infant and raised by adoptive parents in Colorado; her birth mother was addicted to crack cocaine and authorities seized Crow after what they determined was systematic abuse.

Crow's name was not mentioned publicly, but the events of that night may have weighed heavily in the producers' decision to let Scherzinger and Abdul go. Jones, the X Factor's host, was seen to be abrasive and did not appear to have the empathy or common touch with the audience of American Idol's Ryan Seacrest.

The X Factor is due back this fall, but it is already feeling the heat from American Idol. Idol has defied prognosticators' predictions that it would not survive Cowell and Abdul's exit following the 2010 season. In addition, second-year judges Steven Tyler and Jennifer Lopez have a higher profile and gave Idol more cachet than Abdul and Scherzinger could give X Factor.

There have been suggestions that Cowell is about to sign Mariah Carey and possibly Beyonce as judges for The X Factor. Representatives for Cowell, the FOX network and Fremantle Media were not responding to requests for comment late Tuesday.

FOX Entertainment president Kevin Reilly president of alternative programming for the FOX Broadcasting Company, addressed concerns about The X Factor's future earlier this month, at the winter meeting of the TV Critics Association in Los Angeles.

"It inhabits its own space," Reilly said of The X Factor. "There are an awful lot of similarities to Idol and its other imitators, but it's its own show. I loved it. There will be some tweak, but I'm very happy to have it. It's going to be part of us for a long time.

"I will tell you, though, (Cowell) is going to make some changes. If it had twice the ratings, he would still change it. He's relentless that way. I have no idea what they are going to be, but there will be changes."

Abdul out.

Scherzinger and Jones, too.

Mariah Carey in? Wait and watch, as they say.
